snippet.textDisplay: As I thought before playing this game, this turned out to be a true IGAvania in an awesome but maybe too safe way. There have been many amazing Metroidvanias the past years, but IGA still has his unique touch when it comes to the immense variety of battle mechanics. The fact that there are so many shards (if you played the Castlevania Sorrow games, think of them as souls), each able to go up in rank and grade, makes it almost overwhelming. It's basically a huge sandbox with hundreds of toys. I can imagine the team having fun trying to find new shard mechanics. The music by Yamane is solid but far from her best work and the level design is what I found too safe and slightly unmemorable. I will always prefer a beautiful 2D game than 2.5D. Apart from that, the one negative that stands out is the fact that the game is too easy, which prevented me from truly having fun with the various mechanics and find the ones that work best. I felt overpowered to the point that I would beat bosses before I could even see all their moves. The Hard difficulty should have been the default one. In the end, it's just good to have IGA back doing what he does best.
snippet.textOriginal: As I thought before playing this game, this turned out to be a true IGAvania in an awesome but maybe too safe way. There have been many amazing Metroidvanias the past years, but IGA still has his unique touch when it comes to the immense variety of battle mechanics. The fact that there are so many shards (if you played the Castlevania Sorrow games, think of them as souls), each able to go up in rank and grade, makes it almost overwhelming. It's basically a huge sandbox with hundreds of toys. I can imagine the team having fun trying to find new shard mechanics. The music by Yamane is solid but far from her best work and the level design is what I found too safe and slightly unmemorable. I will always prefer a beautiful 2D game than 2.5D. Apart from that, the one negative that stands out is the fact that the game is too easy, which prevented me from truly having fun with the various mechanics and find the ones that work best. I felt overpowered to the point that I would beat bosses before I could even see all their moves. The Hard difficulty should have been the default one. In the end, it's just good to have IGA back doing what he does best.

snippet.textOriginal: TimBagels Yes, I did beat the game already, but this is good to know in case I want to play this game again so thanks anyways.

snippet.textDisplay: @Korji I know that this is over a month old at this point and you definitely already beat the game at this point, but I'll chime in that if you get the electric magic Crystal from one of the bird enemies, you can craft an entirely new Crystal from it that is lightning standing in place above you. Upgrade it to rank 7 or 8, and it will basically melt everything in the game. Alternatively, one of the two directional beams (void beam off abyss dragon, light beam from crafting) are also super powerful.
snippet.textOriginal: @Korji I know that this is over a month old at this point and you definitely already beat the game at this point, but I'll chime in that if you get the electric magic Crystal from one of the bird enemies, you can craft an entirely new Crystal from it that is lightning standing in place above you. Upgrade it to rank 7 or 8, and it will basically melt everything in the game. Alternatively, one of the two directional beams (void beam off abyss dragon, light beam from crafting) are also super powerful.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ooo yikes, I must be garbage then. I’ve been struggling throughout the entire game on NORMAL. I have been playing through the game blindly, but compared to the only other Metriodvania I’ve played, Hollow Knight, I remember dying way less on my first run and I think most people consider that game to be harder. 

Assuming you’ve beaten Bloodstained, I’m curious as to how you beat the final boss (for true ending; I’m getting ptsd of radiance all over again) because I’m currently stuck on that. The first phase is really long and by the time I reach the second I either have no mana or am super weak that I die in two or three hits. You got any tips or suggestions for weapons and crystals, or should I just grind until I’m a certain level before trying again?

snippet.textDisplay: It's interesting that you first thought this theme was composed by Yamane, because that's often what I've thought about the previous DS IGAvanias-- that Yamane composed the entire soundtrack, but I later found out that probably the majority of my favorite tunes in those games were NOT composed by Yamane, but instead by her co-composers, who don't really get much credit (such as Invitation of a Crazed Moon, The Gears go Awry, A Clashing of Waves, Pitch Black Intrusion, Dracula's Tears,  Into the Dark Night, Basement Melody-- all among my favorites, and not composed by Yamane).
snippet.textOriginal: It's interesting that you first thought this theme was composed by Yamane, because that's often what I've thought about the previous DS IGAvanias-- that Yamane composed the entire soundtrack, but I later found out that probably the majority of my favorite tunes in those games were NOT composed by Yamane, but instead by her co-composers, who don't really get much credit (such as Invitation of a Crazed Moon, The Gears go Awry, A Clashing of Waves, Pitch Black Intrusion, Dracula's Tears,  Into the Dark Night, Basement Melody-- all among my favorites, and not composed by Yamane).

snippet.textDisplay: Just finished playing through this game, and I had a blast with it. Really loved it. I can never get enough of IGAvanias. You're right that it's too easy, though. The Rhava Bural just makes the game far too easy. Looking forward to playing through it again on a harder difficulty, though.
snippet.textOriginal: Just finished playing through this game, and I had a blast with it. Really loved it. I can never get enough of IGAvanias. You're right that it's too easy, though.
